person_445.name: Pythagoras
person_445.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

person_263.name: Pluto
person_263.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

person_471.name: WilliamHarvey
person_471.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

person_715.name: Zoroaster
person_715.description: Zoroaster, also known as Zarathustra, is regarded as the spiritual founder of Zoroastrianism.

person_078.name: JohnLocke
person_078.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

person_609.name: Thales
person_609.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_723.name: Epicurus
person_723.description: Ancient Greek philosopher, an atomist and materialist, following in the steps of Democritus and founder of Epicureanism.

person_724.name: Solomon
person_724.description: King of ancient Israel and the son and successor of King David, according to the Hebrew Bible and the Old Testament.

person_725.name: Johann KasparLavater
person_725.description: Swiss poet, writer, philosopher, physiognomist and theologian, best known for his work on physiognomy.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_321.name: GeorgeFordyce
person_321.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

person_693.name: RenéDescartes
person_693.description: French natural philosopher and mathematician, a seminal figure in the emergence of modern philosophy and science. Mathematics was central to his method of inquiry, and he connected the previously separate fields of geometry and algebra into analytic geometry.

person_449.name: François-MarieArouet
person_449.description: Known as Voltaire. French Enlightenment writer, philosopher (philosophe), satirist, and historian. ForMemFRSL.

person_750.name: PierreCorneille
person_750.description: French dramatist, best known for his tragedies.

person_751.name: Bernard Le Bovier deFontenelle
person_751.description: French author and Perpetual Secretary of the Académie Royale des Sciences, 1697-1739. ForMemRSL.

person_190.name: Augustus
person_190.description: Nephew of Julius Ceasar and first Roman emperor.

person_759.name: JohnCalvin
person_759.description: French theologian, pastor and reformer in Geneva during the Protestant Reformation.

person_760.name: Solon
person_760.description: Athenian statesman, lawmaker and poet, who was one of the Seven Sages of Greece, credited with laying the foundations for Athenian democracy

person_761.name: Louis XIV
person_761.description: King of France from 1643 until death - the 'Sun King'.

person_762.name: Spargapises
person_762.description: According to Herodotus, Spargapises was defeated after drinking wine left by the Persian army, which his army was unused to, and becoming intoxicated proved vulnerable to attack; he killed himself after he was captured and shamed.

person_080.name: DavidHume
person_080.description: Influential Scottish philosopher, historian, and economist who expanded on the ideas of John Locke.

person_773.name: Anacreon
person_773.description: Ancient Greek lyric poet, notable for his drinking songs and erotic poems.

person_511.name: Martialis
person_511.description: Roman poet born in Hispania (modern Spain) best known for his twelve books of Epigrams, published in Rome between AD 86 and 103.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_1413.name: Arva
place_1413.description: Likely a misspelling of the fictitious place mentioned previously, Arna.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_873.name: Iran
place_873.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

place_745.name: Languedoc
place_745.description: Languedoc is a historical province of France located on the south coast.

place_874.name: Normandy
place_874.description: A geographical and cultural region in northwestern Europe.

place_877.name: Japan
place_877.description: an island country in East Asia. It is in the northwest Pacific Ocean.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_876.name: Lapland
place_876.description: The largest and northernmost region of Finland.

place_865.name: Greenland
place_865.description: Greenland lies between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans, east of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. It is the world's largest island, and is the location of the northernmost area of the world.

place_031.name: Woburn
place_031.description: Davy mentions Priestley Bog and meadow near Woburn in Elements of Agricultural Chemistry p. 265.

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.
